title: Billbergia strikes $100m mezz deal with Metrics Credit Partners
text:
"We've found that particular non-bank lenders have the ability to be more flexible around loan covenant and terms and are better able to meet needs for 'out of the box' circumstances within a short period," he said.

"The more astute non-bank lenders seem able to professionally address the risk, or lack of, and enter into tailored arrangements."

"We have also found the premium non-bank lenders able to work alongside the senior banks and, where appropriate, team up with allocated equity funds in the form of a joint venture."

Metrics, with ex-NAB long-timer Andrew Lockhart at its helm, has taken a slice of the private lending sector as it works quietly alongside the likes of Qualitas, Alceon, MaxCap and Wingate.

Inside the future Rhodes Central. Supplied

The firm has cut $6.5 billion in loans and has been active in corporate, acquisition, projects and infrastructure and commercial real estate finance.

Like many private lenders. Metrics see its role as crucial in the current tight-credit environment.

Advertisement

"Finance sources, such as ours, also provide for additional flexibility, enabling more tailored lending terms and conditions for the borrower," Mr Lockhart said.

"This can range from timing of repayment as units are sold to adding additional finance as new opportunities arise during development."

Metrics was also one of the earliest private lenders to issue its own investment trusts (LIT), the MCP Master Income Trust and the MCP Income Opportunities Trust, to satisfy the strong demand for loans.

Other lenders such as Qualitas have also issued LITs, which pool investor monies to issue loans such as senior and mezzanine.

It is understood Billbergia has also struck an equity joint-venture with Metrics for another project at King Street in Concord West in Sydney. Both declined to comment on that deal.

Metrics is backed by its own founding partners as well as Ian Macoun’s Pinnacle Investments.
description: The deal will help Billbergia complete the $340 project that will create the two tallest buildings in the Sydney suburb of Rhodes.
